column4: Is there a batch conversion software for ubuntu that when I select a directory, it will add all images in that directory and subdirectories, copy over the original ones and be able to resize them all to like 100x100
'kim' in KDE has this, but I don't know about gnome. Otherwise just use find with -exec or a loop.
you don't really need experience; just one command.
Well what would that command be
(i) cd to the directory you want to be in, then (ii) find . -iname "*.jpg" -exec convert -resize SOMENUMBER% {} {} \;
NOTE: that command is *recursive*. It will resize ALL images in subdirectories to SOMENUMBER percentage
so if I wanted to resize all the bmps too 100x100
like the above, but without the percent, instead with a !
so: find . -iname "*.jpg" -exec convert -resize 100x100! {} {} \;
yes. In each subdirectory as well, so be careful :)
